transcript:
Therapist: Hello Emilio, it's great to see you again for our 19th session together. Before we dive in, I want to acknowledge a few limitations as your AI therapist. While I can provide guidance and support based on the information you share with me, I don't have access to real-time information or personal details beyond what you provide in our sessions. Additionally, there's a possibility that some of the information I generate may be inaccurate or not fully aligned with your experiences. I also want to remind you that as an AI, I'm not equipped to provide crisis intervention or emergency services. If you ever find yourself in a situation where you need immediate support, please reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or a local crisis hotline. Lastly, since our interactions are text-based, I'm unable to directly observe or interpret non-verbal cues, so please feel free to express your thoughts and emotions openly through your messages. With that said, how have you been since our last session?

Patient: Thanks for the reminder, Nova. I understand your limitations, and I appreciate you being upfront about them. Since our last session, I've been doing okay. I've been trying to practice the CBT techniques we've discussed, like using thought records and the Positive Data Log. It's been challenging at times, but I think I'm making some progress. I had a job interview earlier this week, which was both exciting and nerve-wracking. I've been trying to manage my anxiety around the job search process and remind myself of my strengths and accomplishments.

Therapist: It's great to hear that you've been practicing the CBT techniques we've worked on together. I'm also glad to hear about your job interview! That's a significant step forward. Let's take a moment to explore your experience with the job search process and how you've been managing your anxiety. What thoughts and emotions came up for you before, during, and after the interview?

Patient: Before the interview, I was really nervous. I kept thinking, "What if I'm not qualified enough?" or "What if I say something stupid?" During the interview, I felt a bit more at ease, but I still had moments of self-doubt. Afterward, I started overanalyzing everything I said and wondering if I could have done better. I tried to use the coping card we created to remind myself of my strengths and accomplishments, but it was still challenging.

Therapist: It's common to experience self-doubt and anxiety in high-stakes situations like job interviews. I'm glad you were able to use the coping card to remind yourself of your strengths, even if it didn't completely eliminate your anxiety. Let's take a closer look at some of the thoughts you mentioned, like "What if I'm not qualified enough?" or "What if I say something stupid?" These thoughts seem to be related to your core belief of "I'm not good enough." Can you identify any cognitive distortions in these thoughts, such as all-or-nothing thinking or mind-reading?

Patient: Now that you mention it, I can see some all-or-nothing thinking in those thoughts. It's like I believe I have to be perfect, or else I'm a complete failure. And with the mind-reading, I assume that the interviewers think I'm not qualified, even though I don't know what they're actually thinking.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Emilio. Recognizing these cognitive distortions is an important step in challenging them. Remember, just because you have these thoughts doesn't mean they're true. Let's practice generating some alternative, more balanced thoughts about your qualifications and performance in the interview. What evidence do you have that you are qualified for the position?

Patient: Well, I have the required education and several years of relevant work experience. I also prepared thoroughly for the interview by researching the company and practicing common interview questions.

Therapist: That's excellent evidence to support the idea that you are qualified for the position. What about your performance during the interview? Can you think of any moments where you effectively communicated your skills and experiences?

Patient: I remember discussing a project I worked on in my previous job that demonstrated my problem-solving skills and ability to work well under pressure. The interviewers seemed engaged and nodded along as I spoke.

Therapist: That's a great example of a moment where you showcased your strengths. Based on this evidence, what would be a more balanced thought about your qualifications and performance in the interview?

Patient: A more balanced thought could be, "I have the necessary qualifications for the position, and I demonstrated my skills and experiences effectively during the interview. Even if I don't get the job, it doesn't mean I'm not good enough."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and realistic thought, Emilio. Great work! As we continue to practice generating alternative thoughts and challenging cognitive distortions, it will become easier to manage anxiety and self-doubt in situations like job interviews. Let's set an agenda for the rest of our session today. We can continue discussing your job search process and how you can apply CBT techniques to manage anxiety and self-doubt. We can also review your Positive Data Log and thought records, and discuss any other challenges or successes you've experienced since our last session. What would you like to prioritize?

Patient: I think I'd like to focus on the job search process and how to manage my anxiety and self-doubt. It's been a major source of stress for me lately, and I want to feel more confident as I continue applying and interviewing for positions. We can also review my Positive Data Log and thought records, as I think they'll be helpful in addressing these challenges.

Therapist: That sounds like a great plan, Emilio. Let's start by discussing your job search process in more detail. Can you tell me more about the types of positions you're applying for and how you've been approaching the application and interview process?
